documents.text: The Hard Thing About Hard Things: Building a Business When There Are No Easy Answers
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > ul:nth-child(76) > li > p > em > a

documents.text:
A sign in someone's career, that I always take as a big positive: having been a manager, then went back to being an IC.

They are almost always more efficient, having been on "the other side". Often can be great partners to managers and know their reasons on "why not management."
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > div:nth-child(24) > a:nth-child(1) > div:nth-child(2)

documents.text: “What I think a lot of people don’t realize is that when you take on a broader leadership role, while it is true you take on more responsibility, you actually often have less control…. You can’t always just do whatever you want to do. There’s a lot of relationships you need to manage. There’s a lot of alignment that you have to get when you’re driving change.”
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > blockquote:nth-child(59) > p

documents.text: Climbing the engineering leadership ladder forces you to see things from different roles. It’s common to hear people say that after being managers, they were better as individual contributors (ICs) if they returned to that role or that the best managers and ICs have often gone back and forth between the roles.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(22)

documents.text: Perhaps, decades ago, it was ok to just stay in your lane and learn about only your own profession. I don’t know if many lawyers or ad execs really studied the work of being a secretary, for example. However, in the modern tech landscape, not only are there a myriad of different roles (many which didn’t even exist until recently), but the people in these roles must collaborate very closely in order to succeed.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(16)

documents.text:
Some of the best staff and above engineers I know were either managers or leads at some point in their careers.

When I say that they can be more efficient: I mean in the sense of knowing what is worth focusing on - for the sake of the team/company - and what is not.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > div:nth-child(25) > a:nth-child(1) > div:nth-child(2)

documents.text: Lots of engineers treat recruiters as though they are unskilled gatekeepers. “You just need to get past the recruiter,” is a common mentality. Many hiring managers treat recruiters like unskilled order-takers. However, recruiting is a highly skilled job.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(46)

documents.text: You get some degree of understanding of other roles automatically through your work, but if you want to take it further — just as you would with side projects or tutorials to learn new languages — you need to put in some time and effort.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(20)

documents.text: I was floored by the level of subtlety and and strategy discussed in this talk. No “Java AND engineer” searches here. Glen goes into tactics such as natural language search, purposely misspelling words, searching for uncommon terms people might use to describe their jobs, using >50-item Boolean search strings, and eliminating easily-found people to focus the more valuable, less-contacted potential candidates. And that’s only finding the people — we haven’t even gotten into the reach-out message title, channel, content, timing, or personalization yet.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(50)

documents.text: As an engineering manager, I find it sad — and funny — to see Blind posts about how engineering managers are useless and don’t do anything. Don’t we wish!
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(44)

documents.text: on how, when hiring managers really understand and value recruiting — to the point of rolling their sleeves up and doing some traditional “recruiting” tasks themselves — they can be huge assets to their companies by attracting and closing great talent. Synergy between roles works!
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(68) > span:nth-child(5)

documents.text: Just take one obvious thing that recruiters do — they reach out to potential candidates. Sounds simple enough. Just do a little LinkedIn search and pull up people, right?
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(48)

documents.text: .” It could be very helpful, as a manager who’s hiring and working with recruiters, to understand what not to do. This is a point of view that you’re unlikely to get from a simple coffee chat with a recruiter about “So, what do you do in your job?”
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(13) > span:nth-child(5)

documents.text: Do you try to learn about other roles in tech? Are there any resources or approaches you recommend? Let me know in the comments below!
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(85)

documents.text: at LinkedIn Talent connect on Being a Boolean Search Ninja as a recruiter. As he says in a segment around
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(49) > span:nth-child(3)

documents.text: I find it hard to believe that anyone would think engineering managers don’t do much, when we do so much to hold the organization together and keep things running. However, I’m ashamed to admit that until recently, I underestimated what recruiters do.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(45)

documents.text: “The best frontline eng managers in the world are the ones that are never more than 2-3 years removed from hands-on work, full time down in the trenches. The best individual contributors are the ones who have done time in management.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > blockquote:nth-child(23) > p:nth-child(1)

documents.text: Managers often say that once they clear a new level in the organization, their eyes are forever opened to things they didn’t understand before about the overall business and how things really work in a tech company. This has certainly been the case for me.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(27)

documents.text: (Hint: “Current company” and “Past company” are major filters that recruiters use as proxies for candidate quality. It pays to have worked at large or respected companies. LinkedIn might be intensifying this effect by enabling these searches.)
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(67)

documents.text: Beyond reading and watching content, you can also meet with people in these roles one-on-one and ask them about their work, which is a great practice for your career and something I hope to write about more.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(8)

documents.text: Let’s stop and think about it. Recruiting involves arranging in a two-sided marketplace with many shifting variables and time constraints. It takes a combination of many different skills, like sales, cold reach-outs, therapy, match-making, and (as I learned from delving into recruiter content one day), creative Boolean searching.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(47)

documents.text: Also don’t forget to refresh your memory what it’s like to be a software engineering individual contributor, once you break into management, whether by consuming content, reading forums, doing side projects, or actually returning to IC roles at times!
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > ul:nth-child(32) > li:nth-child(13) > p

documents.text: Acting as though you’re in the role yourself and trying to learn how to do it well gives you a greater level of empathy. You’re trying to spend time in their shoes.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > ol:nth-child(11) > li:nth-child(3) > p

documents.text: This is usually a key requirement in engineering leadership job descriptions. You see lots of job descriptions asking that candidates be able to collaborate cross-functionally with product, business stakeholders, QA., etc. as well as to understand the customer and the overall business.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(18)

documents.text: If you think of “cross-functional understanding” as a programming language, it would be one of the most highly sought-after languages in engineering leadership.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(19) > strong

documents.text: I was later contacted by recruiter who mentioned on her profile that she was good at this kind of highly-skilled Boolean search, and I made sure to give her props for it. I will never underestimate the work of finding potential candidates again!
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(53)

documents.text: However, you don’t have to wait to formally switch roles in order to start understanding other roles. You can start understanding other roles now by simply making it a priority to learn.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(29)

documents.text: I’ve had many “aha!” moments this way, where I finally understood, thanks to content meant for other roles, why people in a given role often seem to fixate on certain things or have particular chronic complaints.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(38)

documents.text: If you understand how recruiters use Boolean search on LinkedIn to find candidates, you can apply the knowledge to boost your profile’s SEO or even to inform your career decisions to maximize your marketability.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(66)

documents.text: I encourage watching the talk to build your appreciation for how much skill can go into searching for candidates on LinkedIn (and to get some search ideas if you’re going to be sourcing your own candidates).
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(51)

documents.text: The same goes for any other pair of roles that often to butt heads or fail to understand one another. A little understanding and honesty can go a long way.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(14)

documents.text: When I was thinking about engineering leadership the other day, it occurred to me that this is a good perspective to keep in mind as a leader: Be a…
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(3) > div:nth-child(2) > div:nth-child(2) > div:nth-child(2) > div:nth-child(3) > div:nth-child(2) > a:nth-child(2)

documents.text: Learning about other roles helps you to avoid being the ignorant person who thinks their colleagues are just sitting around or enjoying bossing people around.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(60)

documents.text: When you’re not simply handing work off to another part of the company but rather working together as a giant multi-faceted team, it becomes critical in tech for people to understand and truly “get” each other’s roles.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(17)

documents.text: People sometimes filter themselves or “dumb down” their explanations of their work if they’re explaining their role to outsiders. Seeking out content meant for people in the roles helps you to get around this.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > ol:nth-child(11) > li:nth-child(2) > p

documents.text: For example, if you understand that managers are often spread thin and performance reviews are a lot of work for them, you can organize your achievements into a document that’s easy for them to review and consider while writing your review.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(64)

documents.text: Here are some resources to learn about other roles on their own turf (feel free to suggest any others you recommend!).
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(72)

documents.text: , you can make it a point to be a reasonable hiring manager by clearly defining your needs and helping to source candidates that you like.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(65) > span:nth-child(3)

documents.text: Still, there is something special about actually taking the time to engage with content that is “native” to these other roles.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(9)

documents.text: And the best technical leaders in the world are often the ones who do both. Back and forth.  Like a pendulum.”—

documents.text: Aside from boosting your appreciation for other roles, one of the biggest ways that understanding other roles can help you at work is
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(63) > span:nth-child(1)

documents.text: When you look at “internal” content for a given role, you realize that people in each role are very aware of:
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(40)

documents.text: If you’ve never managed, it can look like managers get paid a lot to sit around and chat with people and have meetings.
documents.elementSelector: html > body > #entry > #main > div:nth-child(2) > div > div:nth-child(1) > div > article > div:nth-child(5) > div:nth-child(1) > div > p:nth-child(57)

documents.text: You can access it anytime, with no need to schedule a meeting, and you can even automate the process by subscribing to newsletters, channels, and podcasts.
